awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: PAGE: Halau Ola Honua "Our living world, living laboratory"
awd_abstract_narration:
A goal of the Tribal Colleges and Universities Program (TCUP) is to increase the science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) instructional and research capacities of specific institutions of higher education that serve the Nation's indigenous students. Expanding the outreach, research, and STEM instructional capacity at these institutions expands the opportunities for students to pursue challenging, rewarding careers in STEM fields, provides for research studies in areas that may be locally relevant, and encourages a faculty community to look beyond the traditional classroom for intellectual and professional growth. This project aligns directly with that goal, and moreover will serve as a model for novel pathways to careers in the geosciences for students underrepresented in that field.

The Partnerships in Geoscience Education (PAGE) collaborative among these Hawaii community colleges and the University of Hawaii Department of Oceanography will implement a strategic approach to increasing the number and success of Native Hawaiians majoring in the geosciences that will include outreach to local high schools, the implementation of a summer bridge that will increase mathematics readiness through calculus, the infusion of Native Hawaiian traditional knowledge into an expanded geoscience curriculum at the participating institutions, locally and culturally relevant research opportunities for undergraduates, community outreach to share the results of that research, and the engagement of environmental science specialists at each participating institution to ensure the greatest likelihood of students? academic success.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of Hawai - Dept. of Oceanography

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
UH Mānoa (UHM), along with the collaborative partner campuses of Windward Community College (lead institution), Honolulu Community College, and Kauaʻi Community College, completed six years of its project, Hālau Ola Honua (HOH), Our living world, living laboratory, a National Science Foundation (NSF) PArtnerships for Geoscience Education (PAGE) grant.The project aimed to increase recruitment and retention of Native Hawaiian (NH) students and further develop institutional instructional capacity in the geosciences.

Three objectives supported this overall goal:

Objective 1: Increase the graduation rate of NH students in geosciences, such that a total of 25 NH students per year will earn a baccalaureate degree from UHM's School of Ocean and Earth Science and Technology (SOEST).

Objective 2: Develop a UH system-wide Environmental Science curricular pathway, which includes formal undergraduate research and field experiences, to formally guide NH students from high school to community college and facilitate the transition from community college to four-year colleges in Hawaiʻi.

Objective 3: Provide service-learning research experiences, which will provide information, skills, and outreach to the communities served as well as the scientific community. The HOH project led to students engaging in rigorous undergraduate research under the guidance of committed staff and faculty. Presentations of research findings to authentic audience validated their work and bolstered confidence. Service-learning opportunities supported student engagement in research and adding relevance, particularly as they related to community and place-based projects. COVID-19 related shutdowns created unanticipated challenges, including two years of cancelled summer programs
due to a need to maintain health and safety and compliance with overall University of Hawaiʻi pandemic percautions.

Despite these setbacks, the team pushed forward and encouraged students to present at virtual conferences. Co-PIs disseminated their project findings through virtual venues as well. The project made strong progresson on most of its objectives, including strengthening the geosciences pathway from community colleges to the University of Hawaiʻi system's four-year institutions at Hilo and UHM. While target numbers of participants were lower than expected due to the pandemic, the project team made strong headway in establishing a strong pathway to expanded educational opportunities for Native Hawaiian students in STEM.


Last Modified: 02/27/2023
Modified by: Michael Guidry
